{{no footnotes|date=July 2012}} {{Infobox newspaper | name = 20 Minuten
({{lang-en|20 Minutes}}) | logo = 20Minuten Logo ab mai 2013.jpg | image = | caption = 20 Minutes logo (since May 2013) | alt = | type = [[Free daily newspaper]] | format = [[Tabloid (newspaper format)|Tabloid]] | owners = [[Express-Zeitung AG]] (jointly owned by [[Tamedia]] (majority holding) and ''[[Berner Zeitung]]'' (17.5%)) | founder = | publisher = | editor = | chiefeditor = | assoceditor = | maneditor = | newseditor = | managingeditordesign = | opeditor = | sportseditor = | photoeditor = | seniorstaff = | staff = | foundation = {{start date and age|1999}} | political = | language = [[German language|German]] | headquarters = [[Switzerland]] | circulation = 494,368 (2010) | sister newspapers = ''[[20 minutes (Switzerland)|20 minutes]]'' ([[French language|French-language]] edition) | ISSN = | oclc = 611676625 | website = [http://www.20min.ch/ 20min.ch] (in [[German language|German]]) }} '''''20 Minuten''''' ({{lang-en|20 Minutes}}) is a free daily newspaper in [[Switzerland]]. ==History and profile== ''20 Minuten'' was first published in 1999 by 20 Minuten Schweiz AG. The direct competitor ''[[Metro International|metropol]]'' was available in Switzerland between 2000 and 2002. ''20 Minuten'' is published in [[Tabloid (newspaper format)|tabloid]] format Since 2005 the newspaper has been owned by [[Express-Zeitung AG]], which is jointly owned by [[Tamedia]] (majority holding) and ''[[Berner Zeitung]]'' (17.5%). In the [[Languages of Switzerland#German|German-speaking parts of Switzerland]], specific editions are made for the regions of [[Basel]], [[Bern]], [[Lucerne]], [[St. Gallen]] and [[Zurich]]. ==Circulation== ''20 Minuten'' is distributed to [[commuter]]s at over 150 train stations across the country. Since September 2004 the German-language edition has been the most widely read daily newspaper in Switzerland, surpassing ''[[Blick]]''. The audited distribution in 2004 was 329,242 ([[WEMF AG]]) and it had a readership of an estimated 782,000. In 2010 its circulation was 494,368 copies, making it the most read daily paper in the country.{{cite news|author1=Cyril Jost|title=The challenges confronting the Swiss press|url=http://www.inaglobal.fr/en/press/article/challenges-confronting-swiss-press|accessdate=23 December 2014|work=InaGlobal|date=4 February 2011}} ==See also== * [[List of free daily newspapers]] * [[List of newspapers in Switzerland]] ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == {{commonscatinline}} * {{official|http://www.20min.ch/ }} (in [[German language|German]]) * [http://www.tamedia.ch/dyn/d/zeitungen/461156.html 20 Minuten] (in [[German language|German]]), profile of the newspaper on the website of [[Tamedia]] ({{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080519091856/http://www.tamedia.ch/dyn/d/zeitungen/461156.html |date=May 19, 2008 }}) {{Press in German-speaking Switzerland}} {{Portal bar|Journalism|Switzerland}} [[Category:1999 establishments in Switzerland]] [[Category:Publications established in 1999]] [[Category:Free daily newspapers]] [[Category:German-language newspapers published in Switzerland]] {{Switzerland-newspaper-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox network | network_name = Al-Resalah | network_logo = | country = [[Saudi Arabia]] | motto = | network_type = [[Satellite television|Satellite]] [[television network]] | available = Middle East, Europe, North Africa, [[Webcast|Internet]] | slogan = "Creative and authentic" | owner = Prince [[Al-Waleed bin Talal]] | key_people = General Manager [[Tareq Al-Suwaidan]]<ref name="Al-Suwaidan_dismissal_BBC_20130818" /> | launch_date = March 1, 2006 | website = http://www.alresalah.net }}
'''Al-Resalah''' ({{lang-ar|قناة الرسالة}}; ''The Message'') is an Arabic language [[satellite television]] channel "to present true [[Islam]]".<ref>owner Prince Al-Waleed bin Talal during the station’s launch</ref><ref name="MEB Journal"/>
It is funded by Prince [[Al-Waleed bin Talal]] of [[Saudi Arabia]], recorded in all over the [[United Arab Emirates]] to [[Morocco]] and [[Kuwait]], and broadcast from [[Cairo]]. Al-Resalah has slots on the [[Arabsat]] and [[Nilesat]] satellites, serving primarily the [[Middle East]], but [[North Africa]] and Europe as well.
The General Manager of Al Resalah was [[Tareq Al-Suwaidan]], a former host at the [[Middle East Broadcasting Center]] (MBC) and a leading member of the Kuwaiti Muslim Brotherhood.<ref>[http://banking.senate.gov/_files/clarke.pdf Statement of Richard A. Clarke Before the United States Senate Banking Committee] 22 October 2003</ref> Tareq Al-Suwaidan was fired from his job in August 2013 by the channel's owner, Prince Alwaleed bin Talal, because of Al-Suwaidan's support for the Moslem Brotherhood.<ref name="Al-Suwaidan_dismissal_BBC_20130818">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-23747381 |title=Saudi prince sacks TV chief for Muslim Brotherhood ties |date=18 August 2013 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=19 August 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2013/08/18/saudi-prince-muslim-brotherhood/2668443/ | work=USA Today | title=TV director fired for ties to Muslim Brotherhood | date=18 August 2013}}</ref>
The head of Al Resalah’s programming in Egypt is [[Ahmed Abu Haiba]], the original producer of [[Amr Khaled]]’s first television program.<ref name="TBS16">[http://www.tbsjournal.com/Otterman.html Fatwas and Feminism: Women, Religious Authority, and Islamic TV] By Sharon Otterman, TBS 16, 2006</ref> The channel's advisory committee includes Sheikh Abdullah Bin Sulaiman Al-Manai (Senior [[Ulema]] Commission, [[Saudi Arabia]]); Dr. Abdallah Omar Naseef (president of the Muslim World Congress); Dr. Hamed Ahmad Al-Refaie (secretary-general of the MWC and president of the International Islamic Forum for Dialogue); Dr. Abdullah Al-Muslih ([[Commission on Scientific Signs in the Quran and Sunnah]]); Sheikh Ali Al-Nashwan (executive manager of the prince's [[Kingdom Holding Company]]'s Humanitarian Division, and religious advisor to the prince); Dr. Abdulaziz Al-Askar (former head of the media department at [[Imam Muhammad ibn Saud Islamic University]]); and Dr. Walid Arab Hashem ([[Consultative Assembly of Saudi Arabia|Shura Council]] member).<ref>The [[Saudi Gazette]], March 7, 2006 cited by [http://memri.org/bin/articles.cgi?Page=subjects&Area=jihad&ID=SP111806 Memri]</ref>
Al Resalah’s website features a list of fatwas by Egypt’s preacher [[Yusuf Al Qaradawi]] approving music videos, [[SMS]] chatting and hosting non-veiled women on its shows.<ref name="MEB Journal">[http://www.mebjournal.com/component/option,com_magazine/func,show_article/id,160/ Religious broadcasters avoid confrontation] by Ayat Basma, MEB Journal, Jan Feb 2008</ref>
[[IslamOnline]] noted that [[Iqraa TV]] was the first [[Islamic]] channel created, followed by others such as [[Al-Fajr TV]] and [[Al-Manar]], but that Al-Resalah had "taken things a step further, pushing forth into the wider realm of entertainment media". Al-Suwaidan too speaks of a nascent revival that has started not only in Muslim countries, but also within Muslim minorities, and that Al-Resalah hopes to contribute to.<ref>[http://www.islamonline.net/servlet/Satellite?c=Article_C&cid=1158658444149&pagename=Zone-English-ArtCulture%2FACELayout Hold Your Breath for a Coming Resalah] By Sarah Sharaf, [[IslamOnline]] Mar. 16, 2006</ref> In February 2008 al-Suwaidan explained that Al-Resalah began with a wide range of programmes, but in the end concentrated on religious features, aiming to be within the top ten by [[Ramadan]] 2008. He claimed that after only one and a half years, Al-Resalah ranks at 18 out of 400 Arab satellite channels and at number one of religious channels outside of Saudi Arabia. The [[target audience]] is Arab, young and female: according to al-Suwaidan, 70% of the viewers are women<ref>[http://www.resetdoc.org/EN/Suwaidan-Conte.php “Islamic and yet modern television” Tareq Al-Suwaidan, producer of Al-Risala] interviewed by Daniela Conte, 5 Feb 2008</ref> (60% according to Abu Haiba<ref name="TBS16"/>).
Some members of the [[Egypt]]ian [[Muslim Brotherhood]] have expressed enthusiasm for the station.<ref>[http://www.csmonitor.com/2006/0502/p01s04-wome.html The new Muslim TV: media-savvy, modern, and moderate] Ursula Lindsey, The Christian Science Monitor, May 2, 2006</ref> [[MEMRI]], a nonprofit press monitoring and analysis organization with headquarters in Washington, DC, has accused al-Reslah of airing anti-Western, [[anti-Semitic]], and pro-Al Qaida content.<ref name="nysun20060621">{{cite news |url=http://www.nysun.com/article/34836 |title=Saudi Billionaire Prince's Hate TV |first=Steven |last=Stalinsky |newspaper= The New York Sun |date=June 21, 2006}}</ref>

{{ref improve|date=April 2012}} The '''Cammell Laird Shipyard occupation''' was a 1984 [[labor dispute]] that was started as the result of [[Layoff|compulsory redundancies]] at the shipyard. It involved the occupation of two vessels to prevent them being removed. The vessels were the Royal Navy Frigate [[HMS Edinburgh (D97)|HMS Edinburgh]] and the Gas Accommodation Rig 'AV-1'.
==References== * [http://www.powerinaunion.co.uk/call-for-action-cammell-laird-occupation-1984/ Call for Action: Cammell Laird occupation 1984]
[[Category:1984 labor disputes and strikes]] [[Category:Labour disputes in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:1984 in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Manufacturing industry strikes]] [[Category:Maritime strikes]]
{{UK-stub}}

revision.text:
{{redirect|The Capital of the World|the short story|The Capital of the World (short story)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Multiple issues| {{peacock|date=August 2009}} {{original research|date=May 2008}} {{globalize|discuss=Talk:Caput Mundi/Archives/2012#Globalize|date=September 2012}} }}
[[File:Roma-Via dei fori imperiali.jpg|thumb|Rome, the imperial capital at the height of the territorial expansion]]
'''''Roma Caput Mundi''''' is a [[Latin language|Latin]] phrase taken to mean "Rome capital of the world" and "Roma capitale del mondo" in Italian (literally: "head of the world";<ref>{{cite web|url=http://latin-phrases.co.uk/dictionary/c/ |title=Dictionary of Latin Phrases and Proverbs: C |publisher=Latin-phrases.co.uk |accessdate=3 January 2012}}</ref> see [[:wiktionary:capital|capital]], [[:wiktionary:capitol|capitol]]). It originates out of a [[classical antiquity|classical European]] understanding of the [[Ecumene|known world]]: [[Europe]], [[North Africa]], and [[Southwest Asia]].
==Rome== {{main|Legacy of the Roman Empire|Roman Catholic church|Rome}} {{Multiple image |total_width = 500 |image1=Rome airal picture.jpg | width1 = 1280 | height1 = 960 |image2=Rome and Vatican 01.jpg | width2 = 4961 | height2 = 3508 |image3=Illuminazione via del corso natale 2011, 03.JPG | width3 = 2816 | height3 = 2112 |footer=[[Via dei Fori Imperiali]], [[Via della Conciliazione]] and [[Via del Corso]]. The term [[First Rome]] is used to refer to the '''Rome of the emperors''', [[Papal States|Second Rome]] refers to the '''Rome of the Popes''', and third Rome refers to the [[Rome of the people]] (as [[capital city]] of [[Italy]]).<ref>[http://students.washington.edu/ageparke/rome.htm Rome Seminar] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081204065057/http://students.washington.edu/ageparke/rome.htm |date=4 December 2008 }}</ref> }}
The influence of Rome in the ancient world began to grow around the 2nd century BC as the Republic expanded across Southern Europe and North Africa. For the next five centuries, Rome would govern much of the known world (of traditional Greco-Roman geography). The cultural influence of the local language of Rome ([[Latin Language|Latin]]) as well as Roman art, architecture, law, religion, and philosophy was significant. The city of [[Rome]] adopted as its nickname ''Caput Mundi'', attributing this to its perception of an enduring power of [[Ancient Rome]] and the [[Roman Catholic Church]].
==Constantinople==
[[Constantinople]] was built as the second Rome by [[Emperor Constantine]] in 330 AD.
The [[Byzantine Empire]] lasted for over a thousand years with the center always at Constantinople, except between 1204 and 1261, when it was centered in the capitals of [[Empire of Nicaea|Nicaea]], [[Trabzon|Trebizond]], and [[Arta, Greece|Arta]]. The city was seen as the "Capital of the World" because of its prime trading position in the center of the medieval world. This privileged position continued even as the capital of the Ottoman Empire. The city was also the center of half of the [[Christian world]] as the seat of the Patriarch of the [[Eastern Orthodox church]]. [[Napoleon I of France|Napoleon Bonaparte]] is quoted as saying, "If the Earth were a single state, Constantinople would be its capital." Today, the city's name is [[Istanbul]].
==London== The capital of the [[British Empire]] was [[London]] - though the empire has since passed, London is one of the world's leading business, financial, and cultural centres, and its influence in politics, education, technology, entertainment, media, fashion and the arts all contribute to its status as a major [[global city]]. Many of the world's largest corporations have their headquarters in London, the city taking a central role as a part of the wider global economy. In addition London in time and on maps is on the [[Prime Meridian]], running directly through [[Greenwich]] (also known as the Greenwich Meridian), with its time zone as [[GMT+0]] ([[UTC+0]]). The decision made at the [[International Meridian Conference]] was due to the dominance of the [[British Empire]]; for logistical reasons, and because the United Kingdom and London remain a major global influence, this position of the Prime Meridian remains.
London is one of the world's largest financial centres.<ref>[https://www.longfinance.net/media/documents/GFCI_24_final_Report_7kGxEKS.pdf] Accessed October 7, 2018.</ref> In addition to this, London has been ranked as the world's capital city in terms of culture, business, Technological readiness and overall economic clout,<ref>http://www.pwc.com/us/en/press-releases/2014/london-tops-pwcs-cities-of-opportunity-study.jhtml</ref> as well as attracting the most foreign investment of any global city.<ref>http://www.londonlovesbusiness.com/business-news/london-attracts-most-foreign-investment-of-any-other-city/1923.article</ref>
The situation of numerous iconic landmarks, such as [[Big Ben]], [[St Paul's Cathedral]], [[Tower Bridge]], the [[Houses of Parliament]], and [[Buckingham Palace]], as well as modern architecture such as the [[30 St Mary Axe|Gherkin]], [[The Shard]], the [[London Eye]] and the [[The O2 (London)|O2]] drew approximately 16.7 million international tourists in 2013, establishing London as the most visited city in the world for international tourists.<ref>https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/london-overtakes-paris-to-become-worlds-most-popular-destination-for-foreign-tourists-9340154.html</ref>
==Plans for Berlin== [[Adolf Hitler]], the dictator of the [[Third Reich]], as part of his proposed [[New Order (political system)|New Order]], planned to make [[Berlin]] the "Caput Mundi", directing [[Albert Speer]] to formulate the ''[[Welthauptstadt Germania]]''—a plan to rebuild Berlin in an [[Reich|Imperial]] [[Nazi architecture|architectural style]]. The central edifice of Berlin would have been the [[Volkshalle]], from which Hitler would have issued his Imperial decrees as [[Occupied Europe|the absolute ruler of Europe]].
==New York City== [[New York City]], the most populous city in the [[United States]], is sometimes described by the [[Latin language|Latin]] phrase "''Novum Caput Mundi''" ("New Capital of the World"); or more commonly by the English phrase, "Capital of the World".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nyc.gov/html/lmec/html/about/nycapital.shtml |title=About New York City |publisher=The City of New York |accessdate=May 1, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407134046/http://www.nyc.gov/html/lmec/html/about/nycapital.shtml |archivedate=7 April 2014 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baruch.cuny.edu/nycdata/forward.htm|title=FORWARD New York – Capital of the Modern World|author=Eugene J. Sherman|publisher=Copyright The Weissman Center for International Business|accessdate=May 1, 2016}}</ref> A leading [[global city]], New York exerts a significant impact upon commerce, finance, media, art, fashion, research, technology, education, and entertainment, its fast pace<ref name=FastPaceNYC1>{{cite news|last=Poliak|first=Shira|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2009-11-19/features/0911180065_1_new-yorkers-fast-paced-big-apple|title=Adjusting To New York City|newspaper=Sun Sentinel|accessdate=May 1, 2016|quote=Additionally, the fast-paced lifestyle of New York City demands adjusting.|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151203093200/http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2009-11-19/features/0911180065_1_new-yorkers-fast-paced-big-apple|archivedate=3 December 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> defining the term ''[[wikt:New York minute|New York minute]]''.<ref name=NewYorkMinuteDefinition>{{cite web|url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/new%20york%20minute|title=Dictionary - Full Definition of NEW YORK MINUTE|publisher=Merriam-Webster|accessdate=May 1, 2016}}</ref> Home to the [[headquarters of the United Nations]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://visit.un.org/wcm/content/ |title=United Nations Visitors Centre |publisher=United Nations |year=2011 |accessdate=May 1, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100924091240/http://visit.un.org/wcm/content |archivedate=24 September 2010 |df=dmy }}</ref> New York is an important center for [[international diplomacy]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nyc.gov/html/ia/html/home/home.shtml |title=NYC Mayor's Office for International Affairs |publisher=The City of New York |accessdate=May 1, 2016}}</ref> and has been described as the cultural and financial capital of the world,<ref name="cultura1">{{cite web |url=http://www.iceland.is/iceland-abroad/us/nyc/cultural-affairs/ |title=Consulate General of Iceland New York Culture |publisher=Consulate General of Iceland New York |accessdate=May 1, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130205061848/http://www.iceland.is/iceland-abroad/us/nyc/cultural-affairs/ |archivedate=5 February 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name="culture2">{{cite web |url=http://www.latvia-newyork.org/english/ |title=Consulate of Latvia in New York |publisher=Consulate of Latvia |accessdate=May 1, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130208223706/http://www.latvia-newyork.org/english/ |archivedate=8 February 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name="culture3">{{cite web |url=http://www.baruch.cuny.edu/nycdata/Culture/intro.htm |title=Introduction to Chapter 14: New York City (NYC) Culture |publisher=The Weissman Center for International Business Baruch College/CUNY 2011 |accessdate=May 1, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130505181316/http://www.baruch.cuny.edu/nycdata/culture/intro.htm |archivedate=5 May 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name = "culture4">{{cite web |url=http://catalogue.nla.gov.au/Record/371497 |title=New York, Culture Capital of the World, 1940–1965 / edited by Leonard Wallock ; essays by Dore Ashton ... [et al.] |publisher=NATIONAL LIBRARY OF AUSTRALIA |accessdate=May 1, 2016}}</ref><ref name=WorldEconomicAndFinancialSuperCenter>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/top-8-cities-by-gdp-china-vs-the-us-2011-8 |title=Top 8 Cities by GDP: China vs. The U.S. |quote=For instance, Shanghai, the largest Chinese city with the highest economic production, and a fast-growing global financial hub, is far from matching or surpassing New York, the largest city in the U.S. and the economic and financial super center of the world. |publisher=Business Insider, Inc |date=July 31, 2011 |accessdate=May 1, 2016}}</ref><ref name = "culture5">{{cite web |url=http://www.philippineairlines.com/news-and-events/pal-advises-passengers-come-airport-early-2/ |title=PAL sets introductory fares to New York |publisher=Philippine Airlines |accessdate=May 1, 2016}}</ref> despite not being the modern capital of the United States or even of [[New York State]]. As many as 800 languages are spoken in New York City, making it the most linguistically diverse city in the world.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/29/nyregion/29lost.html?hpw|title=Listening to (and Saving) the World’s Languages|accessdate=29 April 2010 | work=The New York Times | first=Sam | last=Roberts | date=May 1, 2016}}</ref>
Numerous national and international private corporations have headquarters in New York City. Anchored by [[Wall Street]], in [[Lower Manhattan]], New York City has been called the world's principal [[financial center]],<ref name=NYCDominantFinancialCenter>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-survey-markets/united-states-top-britain-second-in-financial-activity-think-tank-idUSKCN1LK2TM|title=United States top, Britain second in financial activity: think-tank|author=Huw Jones|publisher=Thomson Reuters|date=September 4, 2018|accessdate=September 4, 2018|quote=Think-tank New Financial’s study, which focuses on the “raw” value of actual domestic and international financial activity like managing assets and issuing equity, underscored the overall dominance of New York as the world’s top financial center.}}</ref> as well as most economically powerful city<ref name=EconomicallyPowerful2015>{{cite web|url=http://www.citylab.com/work/2015/03/sorry-london-new-york-is-the-worlds-most-economically-powerful-city/386315/|title=Sorry, London: New York Is the World's Most Economically Powerful City|author=Richard Florida|publisher=The Atlantic Monthly Group|date=3 March 2015|accessdate=25 March 2015|quote=Our new ranking puts the Big Apple firmly on top.}}</ref><ref name=WorldEconomicAndFinancialSuperCenter/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.philippineairlines.com/news-and-events/pal-advises-passengers-come-airport-early-2/|title=PAL sets introductory fares to New York|publisher=Philippine Airlines|accessdate=25 March 2015}}</ref><ref> {{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2012/05/what-is-the-worlds-most-economically-powerful-city/256841/|title=What Is the World's Most Economically Powerful City?|author=Richard Florida|publisher=The Atlantic Monthly Group|date=8 May 2012|accessdate=25 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-11-24/new-york-boosts-lead-on-london-as-leading-finance-center.html|title=New York Boosts Lead on London as Leading Finance Center|author=John Glover |publisher=Bloomberg L.P|date=23 November 2014|accessdate=23 March 2015}}</ref><ref>[https://www.longfinance.net/media/documents/GFCI_24_final_Report_7kGxEKS.pdf] Accessed October 7, 2018.</ref> and is home to the [[New York Stock Exchange]], the world's largest [[stock exchange]] per total [[market capitalization]] of its listed companies.<ref name=NYSEhighestcap>{{cite web|url=http://www.world-exchanges.org/files/2013_WFE_Market_Highlights.pdf|title=2013 WFE Market Highlights|page=5|publisher=World Federation of Exchanges|accessdate=24 March 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140327112731/http://www.world-exchanges.org/files/2013_WFE_Market_Highlights.pdf|archivedate=27 March 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The [[New York metropolitan area|New York City metropolitan region]] is defined by both the [[List of Metropolitan Statistical Areas|Metropolitan Statistical Area]] (19.9 million residents in 2013)<ref name=2013metroest>{{cite web|url=https://www.census.gov/newsroom/releases/pdf/CB14-51_countymetropopest2013tables.pdf|title=The 10 Largest Metro Areas on July 1, 2013|publisher=U.S. Census Bureau|accessdate=27 March 2014}}</ref> and the [[List of Combined Statistical Areas|Combined Statistical Area]] (23.5 million residents in 2013).<ref name=2013combinedest>{{cite web|url=https://www.census.gov/popest/data/metro/totals/2013/index.html|title=Annual Estimates of the Resident Population: April 1, 2010 to July 1, 2013 - Combined Statistical Area; and for Puerto Rico|publisher=U.S. Census Bureau|accessdate=28 June 2014}}</ref> In 2013, the MSA produced a [[gross metropolitan product]] (GMP) of nearly US$1.39 trillion,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.statista.com/statistics/183808/gmp-of-the-20-biggest-metro-areas/|title=Gross Metropolitan Product (GMP) of the United States in 2013, by metropolitan area (in billion current U.S. dollars)|publisher=Statista|accessdate=12 September 2014}}</ref> while in 2012, the CSA<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/sites/default/files/omb/bulletins/2013/b13-01.pdf|title=Revised Delineations of Metropolitan Statistical Areas, Micropolitan Statistical Areas, and Combined Statistical Areas, and Guidance on Uses of the Delineations of These Areas |page=106|publisher=Executive Office of the President – Office of Management and Budget|accessdate=27 June 2014}}</ref> generated a GMP of over US$1.55 trillion, both ranking first nationally by a wide margin and behind the [[gross domestic product|GDP]] of only twelve nations and eleven nations, respectively.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usmayors.org/metroeconomies/2013/201311-report.pdf|title=U.S. Metro Economies (note CSA 2012 GMP total includes sum of New York, Bridgeport, New Haven, Allentown, Trenton, Poughkeepsie, and Kingston MSA 2012 GMP values cited)|pages=9 through 18 in Appendix Tables|publisher=IHS Global Insight, The United States Conference of Mayors, and The Council on Metro Economies and the New American City|date=November 2013|accessdate=27 June 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150305224230/http://www.usmayors.org/metroeconomies/2013/201311-report.pdf|archivedate=5 March 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
New York City has been ranked first among cities across the globe in attracting [[capital (economics)|capital]], business, and tourists.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-04-13/beijing-breaks-into-top-ten-in-rankings-by-a-t-kearney.html|title=Beijing Breaks Into Top Ten in Rankings by A.T. Kearney|author=Simon Kennedy|publisher=Bloomberg L.P|date=13 April 2014|accessdate=2 May 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-03-12/new-york-city-tops-global-competitiveness-london-is-no-2-economist-says.html|title=New York City Tops Global Competitiveness, Economist Report Says|author=Michelle Kaske|publisher=Bloomberg L.P.|date=12 March 2012|accessdate=2 May 2014}}</ref> [[Tourism in New York City|Tourism]] is vital to New York City, and many districts and [[New York City landmark|landmarks in New York City]] have become well known, as the city received a record high 56 million tourists in 2014,<ref name=NYCTouristCount>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/02/02/us-usa-newyork-tourism-idUSKBN0L61XM20150202|title=New York City tourism hit record high in 2014, officials say|publisher=Thomson Reuters|author=Ellen Wulfhorst, editing by Eric Beech|date=2 February 2015|accessdate=13 April 2015}}</ref> generating an all-time high US$61.3 billion in overall economic impact for New York City in 2014.<ref name=NYCTouristCount/> Several sources have ranked New York the most photographed city in the world.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://petapixel.com/2013/12/27/google-maps-photographed-places-world/|title=Google Maps Out the Most Photographed Places in the World|author=DL Cade|publisher=PetaPixel|date=27 Dec 2013|accessdate=23 January 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140124043133/http://petapixel.com/2013/12/27/google-maps-photographed-places-world/|archivedate=24 January 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://petapixel.com/2013/12/13/liked-instagram-pic-2013-features-justin-bieber-confirms-fears/|title=Most Instagrammed Locations and Cities of 2013 Revealed, as Well as Most-Liked Photo|author=DL Cade|publisher=PetaPixel|date=13 Dec 2013|accessdate=23 January 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201100115/http://petapixel.com/2013/12/13/liked-instagram-pic-2013-features-justin-bieber-confirms-fears/|archivedate=1 February 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/43240059/ns/travel-travel_tips/#.Utnoezgo47o|title=The 25 most photographed places on Earth|author=Sean O'Neill|publisher=NBCNews.com|date=12 June 2011|accessdate=23 January 2014}}</ref> [[Times Square]], at the hub of the [[Broadway theater]] district, is nicknamed The Crossroads of the World,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://digitaljournalist.org/issue0402/at_intro.html|title=New York in the 70s: A Remembrance|author=Allan Tannenbaum|publisher=© The Digital Journalist|accessdate=May 1, 2016}}</ref> [[List of places referred to as the Center of the Universe|The Center of the Universe]],<ref>[http://www.hercampus.com/school/nyu/explore-manhattan-neighborhoods-center-universe-aka-times-square-0 Explore Manhattan Neighborhoods: The Center of the Universe (aka Times Square)]. Her Campus (March 22, 2011). Retrieved on May 1, 2016.</ref> and the "heart of the world".<ref name=TransformingTimesSquare>{{cite news|url=http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/08/24/new-york-today-change-with-the-times/|title=New York Today:Transforming Times Square|author=Noah Remnick and Tatiana Schlossberg|newspaper=The New York Times|date=August 24, 2015|accessdate=May 1, 2016}}</ref>
==Washington, D.C.== The capital of the United States of America and the seat of the [[Federal government of the United States|U.S. federal government]], [[Washington, D.C.]] also holds the headquarters of important international organizations such as the [[World Bank]], the [[International Monetary Fund]], and the [[Organization of American States]]. The signing of the [[North Atlantic Treaty]] took place in Washington;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.trumanlibrary.org/nato/nato.htm |title=North Atlantic Treaty |publisher=Truman Library |accessdate=3 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nato.int/cps/en/natolive/official_texts_17120.htm |title=NATO – Official text: The North Atlantic Treaty, 04-Apr. 1949 |publisher=Nato.int |date=9 December 2008 |accessdate=3 January 2012}}</ref> establishing [[NATO]] which took part in the [[Cold War]], and by its end, Washington was dubbed by the ''Washington Post'' as the capital of the world.<ref>[[David S. Broder|Broder, David S.]] [https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/washingtonpost/access/72566980.html?dids=72566980:72566980&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=FEB+18%2C+1990&author=David+S.+Broder&pub=The+Washington+Post&desc=Nation's+Capital+in+Eclipse+as+Pride+and+Power+Slip+Away%3B+Some+See+Descent+as+Steep+and+Permanent+but+Others+Regard+It+as+Temporary&pqatl=google "Nation's Capital in Eclipse as Pride and Power Slip Away"], ''[[The Washington Post]]'', 18 February 1990. Retrieved 18 October 2010. "In the days of the Truman Doctrine, the Marshall Plan and the creation of NATO, [Clark Clifford] said, ''we saved the world, and Washington became the capital of the world.''"</ref>
==See also== * [[Globalization]] * [[Global city|World City]] * [[Welthauptstadt Germania]] * [[Washington Consensus]] * Other cities that played major roles: [[Paris#18th_and_19th_centuries|Paris]] (Lutetia Parisiorum)(particularly at the times of Louis XIV and Napoleon Bonaparte, but not only. Sometime between the 18th and 19th century Paris started being named as the City of Lights (Ville Lumière)); [[Madrid#Modern_Age|Madrid]] (at the time of Charles V and Felipe II); [[Lisbon#Early_Modern|Lisbon]] (in the 15th century);
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox Union |name= Cobas |country= [[Italy]] |affiliation= |members= |full_name= Confederazione dei Comitati di Base |native_name= |image= [[File:Cobas logo.png]] |founded= |current= |head= |dissolved_date= |dissolved_state= |merged_into= |office= [[Rome]], Italy |people= |website= [http://www.cobas.it/ www.cobas.it] |footnotes= }} <!-- Include all unused fields for future use. See [[template talk:Infobox Union]] for usage. --> The '''Confederazione dei Comitati di Base''' (Cobas) is a [[wikt:rank and file|rank and file]]<ref name="Gall1995"/> [[national trade union center|trade union center]] in [[Italy]]. It was formed in the late 1980s by members who were dissatisfied with the leadership of the three main Italian confederations ([[CGIL]], [[Italian Confederation of Workers' Trade Unions|CISL]] and [[Italian Labour Union|UIL]]). Many of its members see it as [[syndicalist]], but it has also courted the [[Trotskyist]] group, the [[League for the Fifth International]] with whom it shared a platform at the anti-G8 protests in [[Rostock]] in 2007.
Cobas regard themselves as [[wikt:rank and file|rank and file]] unions in contrast to the traditional, hierarchical unions that impose compromises on their members.<ref name="Gall1995">Gall (1995) quotation: {{quotation|[...] unofficial rank and file committees, Comitati di Base, known as Cobas, who have been at the forefront organising militant strike action in many industrial sectors since 1987. The COBAS have led strikes of railway workers, teachers, airport workers and bank workers as well as being heavily involved in organising general strikes and demonstrations against the government's austerity measures. For example, in 1992, they alone, and against the Italian Communist Party, organised a 300,000 strong demonstration in Rome against rising unemployment and have called for half-day general strikes to be extended.}}</ref><ref name="Gamble2007p209"/><ref>Wright (1999)</ref> Comparable "rank and file" labor unions exist in France: the [[Fédération Syndicale Unitaire]] (FSU), and the [[Solidaires Unitaires Démocratiques]] (SUD) and their confederation in the [[Union syndicale G10 Solidaires|Group of 10]].<ref name="Gamble2007p209">Gamble (2007) p.209</ref>
==History== The [[factory councils]] became more and more popular during the 1970s, and their co-existence with the traditional unions increased unionization. In 1978, the mainstream unions recentralised power to prevent rank-and-file practices and rules outside of their control.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=SY1N3d-O-rgC&pg=PA471 Changing industrial relations in Europe By Anthony Ferner, Richard Hyman](1998) p.471</ref>
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==References== *[[Gregor Gall|Gall, Gregor]] (1995) [http://cnc.sagepub.com/content/19/1/9.extract ''The Emergence of a Rank and File Movement: the Comitati di Base in the Italian Worker's Movement''], in ''[[Capital & Class]]'' *Gamble, Andrew (2007) [https://books.google.com/books?id=Ah_FAAAAIAAJ ''Labour, the state, social movements and the challenge of neo-liberal globalisation''], Manchester University Press *Wright, Steve (1999) [http://www.driftline.org/cgi-bin/archive/archive_msg.cgi?file=spoon-archives/aut-op-sy.archive/aut-op-sy_1999/aut-op-sy.9912&msgnum=270&start=28231 ''Radical Unions in Italy''] in [[Industrial Workers of the World#In Australia|''Direct Action'']] (journal of the [[Industrial Workers of the World]] in Australia), #171, Summer 1999-2000.
==Further reading== *{{cite book | year = 2005 | title = Trade Unions of the World | editor = [[International Centre for Trade Union Rights|ICTUR]] et al., | edition = 6th | publisher = John Harper Publishing | location = London, UK | isbn = 0-9543811-5-7 }} *Patrick* OCL Caen (2001)[https://web.archive.org/web/20041229215845/http://www.mercatiesplosivi.com/dibase/page206.htm ''SUD: viaggio all'interno del nuovo sindacalismo''], in ''Sindacalismo di Base'' n.12
==External links== * [http://www.cobas.it/ Official site] - Italian only * [https://web.archive.org/web/20041208022448/http://www.mercatiesplosivi.com/dibase/default.htm sindacalismo di BASE - Azione diretta per l'autorganizzazione]
{{Portal|Organized labour}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox Union |name= CNT-F |country= [[France]] |affiliation= |members= 3700 - 4200 (december 2008) |full_name= National Confederation of Labour |native_name= Confédération nationale du travail |image= [[Image:CNT black cat logo.png|175px]] |founded= 1946 |current= |head= No chief |dissolved_date= |dissolved_state= |merged_into= |office= [[Paris]], France |people= |website= CNT Vignoles : [http://www.cnt-f.org/ www.cnt-f.org]
CNT AIT : [http://www.cnt-ait.fr/ cnt-ait.fr] |footnotes= }} The '''CNT-F''' ('''Confédération nationale du travail''') or National Confederation of Labour is a [[France|French]] [[anarcho-syndicalist]] union. It was founded in 1946 by [[Spain|Spanish]] [[anarcho-syndicalism|anarcho-syndicalists]] in exile, and former members of [[Confédération Générale du Travail-Syndicaliste Révolutionnaire]] (CGT-SR), its name is derived from the Spanish CNT, the [[Confederación Nacional del Trabajo]]. == Division == [[Image:CNT - Anti-EPR demonstration in Toulouse 0206 2007-03-17.jpg|thumb|CNT-F]] Nowadays, two French organisations share the name CNT: * the ''CNT-Vignoles'' (or ''CNT-f''), from the name of the street where their main office in Paris is located. It contains the most members of the two organisations. They decline the term [[anarchist]], preferring to call themselves "[[revolutionary]] [[Trade union|unionist]]" (''syndicalistes révolutionnaires'').Bénédicte Rallu, [http://www.politis.fr/article1293.html Le réveil des chats noirs] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051219225836/http://www.politis.fr/article1293.html |date=2005-12-19 }}, ''[[Politis (France)|Politis]]'', 4 April 2005 (Interviews of members of the CNT-Vignoles {{Fr icon}} They accept the terms of the 1906 [[Charter of Amiens]], the Charter of Lyon (1926) and the charter of Paris (1946). They also accept participation in the professional elections and collaboration with others unions. * the ''CNT-AIT''. This is the French section of the [[International Workers Association]] (IWA). They define themselves as anarchosyndicalist, while they have clear influences from [[council communism]], worker anarchism of the [[Federación Obrera Regional Argentina]] (FORA) and the [[Situationist International]]. {{Anarcho-syndicalism sidebar}} == See also == {{Portal|Organized labour}} *[[Anarchism in France]] *''[[Confederación Nacional del Trabajo]]'' (CNT), its Spanish sister trade union *''[[List of trade unions in Spain|Confederacion General del Trabajo de España]]'' (CGT), Spanish anarchosyndicalist trade union *[[Étienne Roda-Gil]], songwriter and screenwriter *[[Léo Ferré]], songwriter *''[[Confédération générale du travail unitaire]]'', French trade union (1921–1936) ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons|Confédération nationale du travail (France)}} * [http://www.cnt-f.org/ CNT-Vignoles Homepage] * [http://www.cnt-ait.fr/ CNT-AIT] {{DEFAULTSORT:Confederation nationale du travail}} [[Category:Syndicalism]] [[Category:Trade unions in France]] [[Category:International Workers' Association]] [[Category:Trade unions established in 1946]] [[Category:Far-left politics in France]] [[Category:Anarchist organizations in France]] [[Category:Anarchist organizations in Europe]] [[Category:National trade union centers of France]] [[Category:Revolutionary Syndicalism]] {{Anarchism-stub}} {{France-org-stub}} {{Europe-trade-union-stub}}

{{Infobox diocese | jurisdiction = Diocese <!-- Type of jurisdiction: i.e. Diocese or Archdiocese --> | name = Espoo <!-- Place name(s) of the diocese (or archdiocese) --> | latin = <!-- Latin name of the diocese (or archdiocese) --> | local = {{lang|fi|Espoon hiippakunta}} <!-- Name in the native language --> | image = Espoon tuomiokirkko.jpg | image_size = 100 | image_alt = Coat of arms of the Diocese of Espoo.svg | caption = Espoo Cathedral <!---- Locations ----> | country = [[Finland]] | territory = | province = Turku & Finland | metropolitan = Archbishop of Turku & Finland | archdeaconries = | deaneries = | subdivisions = | coordinates = <!-- Use {{coord}} --> <!---- Statistics ----> | area_km2 = <!-- Area in square kilometers, automatically converted --> | area_sqmi = <!-- Area in square miles, automatically converted --> | area_footnotes = | population = | population_as_of = | catholics = <!-- Number of Catholics in the diocese --> | catholics_percent = | parishes = 25 <!-- Number of parishes in the diocese --> | churches = <!-- Number of churches in the diocese --> | congregations = <!-- Number of congregations in the diocese --> | schools = <!-- Number of church supported schools in the diocese --> | members = 550 000<!-- Number of members in the diocese --> <!---- Information ----> | denomination = [[Evangelical Lutheran Church of Finland]] | rite = <!-- e.g., [[Latin Rite]] --> | established = 2004 | cathedral = [[Espoo Cathedral]] <!-- Cathedral that serves as the seat of the diocese --> | cocathedral = | patron = <!-- Patron saint(s) of the diocese (or archdiocese) --> | patron_title = <!-- Use to override the default label "Patron saint" --> | priests = <!-- Number of priests in the diocese --> <!---- Current leadership ----> | pope = <!-- DO NOT CHANGE. This will update the Popes Automatically as they change --> | patriarch = | major_archbishop = | bishop = [[Kaisamari Hintikka]] <!-- Name and title of the current ordinary of the diocese --> | bishop_title = <!-- Type of ordinary: i.e. Bishop or Archbishop. Default is Bishop --> | metro_archbishop = [[Tapio Luoma]] <!-- Name of the Metropolitan Archbishop of the Ecclesiastical Province --> | coadjutor = | suffragans = <!-- List most senior first (usually reckoned by date of consecration); use | suffragan = for one --> | auxiliary_bishops = <!-- List most senior first (usually reckoned by date of consecration) --> | apostolic_admin = | vicar_general = | episcopal_vicar = | archdeacons = <!-- List most senior first (usually reckoned by date of first collation); use | archdeacon = for one--> | emeritus_bishops = <!-- List most senior first (usually reckoned by date of consecration) --> <!---- Map ----> | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = <!---- Website ----> | website = <!-- [http://example.com example.com] --> | footnotes = }} [[File:Coat of arms of the Diocese of Espoo.svg|thumb|240 px]] The '''Diocese of Espoo''' ([[Finnish language|Finnish]] ''Espoon hiippakunta'') is the newest of the nine [[diocese]]s of the [[Evangelical Lutheran Church of Finland]]. The diocese came into existence in 2004 after the [[Diocese of Helsinki]] was split in two.
The seat of the diocese is the [[Espoo Cathedral]] and its first bishop was [[Mikko Heikka]].
After Heikka's successor [[Tapio Luoma]] was elected Archbishop in 2018, [[Kaisamari Hintikka]] was elected to succeed him in 2019.
==List of Bishops== * [[Mikko Heikka]] 2004-2011 * [[Tapio Luoma]] 2012-2018 * [[Kaisamari Hintikka]] 2019- ==External links== * [http://espoonhiippakunta.evl.fi/english/ Official website]
{{Finland-stub}}

page.title: Directorate-General for Migration and Home Affairs

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{Politics of the European Union}} The '''Directorate-General for Migration and Home Affairs''' (DG HOME) is a [[Directorate-General]] of the [[European Commission]]. The role of the body is to ensure the EU's security, to build a common EU migration and asylum policy, and to promote dialogue and cooperation with non-EU countries.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://ec.europa.eu/home-affairs/who-we-are/about-us_en|title=DG HOME: About us|last=|first=|date=2017-10-13|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-10-13}}</ref> Thereby, it contributes to the [[Area of freedom, security and justice]] (AFSJ).
==Structure== As well as a "shared resources" directorate (budget, human resources, etc.), the directorate-general has five functional directorates: *Directorate A: Strategy and General Affairs *Directorate B: Migration and Mobility *Directorate C: Migration and Protection *Directorate D: Security *Directorate E: Migration and Security Funds.
Additionally, there are the following Migration and Home Affairs [[Agencies of the European Union|Agencies]]: * [[eu-Lisa]] * [[European Border and Coast Guard Agency|Frontex]] * [[European Asylum Support Office|EASO]] * [[Europol]] * [[European Police College|Cepol]] * [[European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction|EMCDDA]] The current Director General of DG HOME is [[Matthias Ruete]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ec.europa.eu/home-affairs/who-we-are/director-general_en|title=DG HOME: Our Director General|last=|first=|date=2017-10-13|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-10-13}}</ref> Relating [[European Commissioner|European Commissioners]] are the [[European Commissioner for Home Affairs|European Commissioner for Migration, Home Affairs, and Citizenship]] and the [[European Commissioner for the Security Union]].
=== Directorate A: Strategy and General Affairs === The ''Directorate Strategy and General Affairs'' is subdivided into (1) inter-institutional relations and citizenship, (2) legal affairs, (3) international coordination, and (4) knowledge hub for migration and security.
=== Directorate B: Migration and Mobility === The ''Directorate Migration and Mobility'' includes (1) legal migration and integration, (2) visa policy and document security, (3) information systems for borders and security, and (4) innovation and industry for security.
=== Directorate C: Migration and Protection === The ''Directorate Migration and Protection'' comprises (1) irregular migration and return policy, (2) border management and Schengen, (3) asylum, and (4) migration management support.
=== Directorate D: Security === The ''Directorate Security'' comprises (1) police cooperation and information exchange, (2) terrorism and radicalisation, (3) organised crime and drugs policy, and (4) cybercrime.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ec.europa.eu/home-affairs/sites/homeaffairs/files/who-we-are/dg-home-affairs-chart/docs/organigramme_en.pdf|title=DG HOME: Organisation Chart|last=|first=|date=2017-10-13|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-10-13}}</ref> This includes the fight against terrorism and organised crime, by promoting police cooperation and by preparing to swiftly respond to emerging crises.<ref name=":0" />
=== Directorate E: Migration and Security Funds === This Directorate is made up of (1) union actions, (2) national programmes for South and East Europe; AMIF/ISF Committee, (3) national programmes for North and West Europe;Evaluations; MFF, and (4) budget and control.
In order to achieve its goals, the European Commission has released several agends. Current major agendas related to the DG HOME are the [[European Agenda on Security]] (2015)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ec.europa.eu/home-affairs/sites/homeaffairs/files/e-library/documents/basic-documents/docs/eu_agenda_on_security_en.pdf|title=The European Agenda on Security|last=|first=|date=2015|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-10-13}}</ref>, the [[European Agenda on Migration]] (2015)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ec.europa.eu/home-affairs/sites/homeaffairs/files/what-we-do/policies/european-agenda-migration/background-information/docs/communication_on_the_european_agenda_on_migration_en.pdf|title=European Agenda on Migration|last=|first=|date=2015|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-10-13}}</ref>, and the [[Cybersecurity Strategy for the European Union]] (2013)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ec.europa.eu/digital-single-market/en/news/eu-cybersecurity-plan-protect-open-internet-and-online-freedom-and-opportunity-cyber-security|title=EU Cybersecurity plan to protect open internet and online freedom and opportunity - Cyber Security strategy and Proposal for a Directive|last=|first=|date=2013|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-10-13}}</ref>. Other major agendas are the [[EU Global Strategy]] (2016)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://europa.eu/globalstrategy/sites/globalstrategy/files/pages/files/eugs_review_web_13.pdf|title=Shared Vision, Common Action: A Stronger Europe A Global Strategy for the European Union’s Foreign And Security Policy|last=|first=|date=2016|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-10-13}}</ref>, the [[White Paper on the Future of Europe]] (2017)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ec.europa.eu/commission/sites/beta-political/files/white_paper_on_the_future_of_europe_en.pdf|title=The White Paper on the Future of Europe|last=|first=|date=2017|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-10-13}}</ref>, the [[European Energy Security Strategy]] (2014).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/PDF/?uri=CELEX:52014DC0330&from=EN|title=European Energy Security Strategy|last=|first=|date=2014|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-10-13}}</ref>
==History== DG HOME was created in 2010 when the DG Justice, Freedom and Security was split into DG HOME and the [[Directorate-General for Justice]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Commission completes internal reshuffle|date=3 June 2010|work=[[EurActiv]]|url=http://www.euractiv.com/future-eu/commission-completes-internal-re-news-494849}}</ref>
==See also== * [[European Civil Service]] (i.a. for all DGs) * [[European Commissioner for Home Affairs|European Commissioner for Migration, Home Affairs, and Citizenship]] * [[European Commissioner for the Security Union]] * [[European Commissioner for Justice, Fundamental Rights and Citizenship]] * [[Directorate-General for Justice|Directorate-General for Justice and Consumers]] * [[Justice and Home Affairs Council]] (Council of the European Union) * [[Area of freedom, security and justice]] *[[Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union]] *[[Four Freedoms (European Union)|Four Freedoms]] *[[European Convention on Human Rights]] *[[Universal Declaration of Human Rights]] *[[Police and Judicial Co-operation in Criminal Matters]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://ec.europa.eu/dgs/home-affairs/index.html DG Home Affairs] *[https://ec.europa.eu/info/sites/info/files/migration-and-home-affairs-organisation-chart_en.pdf Organisation Chart of DG Home] *[https://ec.europa.eu/commission/commissioners/2014-2019_en The Commissioners] - official homepage *[https://ec.europa.eu/commission/commissioners/2014-2019/avramopoulos_en European Commissioner for Migration, Home Affairs, and Citizenship]- official homepage * [https://ec.europa.eu/commission/commissioners/2014-2019/king_en European Commissioner for the Security Union] - official homepage
{{Eu-directorates-general}}
[[Category:Directorates-General in the European Commission|Home Affairs]]
{{EU-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2011}} {{Use Australian English|date=August 2011}} {{Infobox flag |Name = Tasmania |Article = |Image = Flag of Tasmania.svg |Nickname = |Morenicks = |Use = |Symbol = |Proportion = 1:2 |Adoption = 25 September 1876 |Design = State badge of a red lion passant on white disk, on a defaced British Blue Ensign |Type = National }} [[File:Badge of Tasmania.svg|thumb|100px|The state badge]] The current state '''flag of Tasmania''' was officially adopted following a proclamation by [[Tasmania]]n colonial [[Governor of Tasmania|Governor]] [[Frederick Aloysius Weld|Sir Frederick Weld]] on 25 September 1876, and was first published in the ''Tasmanian Gazette'' the same day. The governor's proclamation here were three official flags, they being the Governor's flag, the Tasmania Government vessel flag, and a Tasmania merchant flag. Up until 1856 when Tasmania was granted [[responsible government|responsible self-government]], the [[Union flag]] and the [[British ensign]] were primarily used on state occasions.{{cite web| url = http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/1355542/flag-of-Tasmania | title = Tasmania, flag of. | accessdate =2008-09-10| year= 2008 | publisher = Encyclopædia Britannica}} The flag consists of a [[Defacement (flag)|defaced]] British [[Blue Ensign]] with the state badge located in the [[Flag terminology#Description of standard flag parts and terms|fly]]. The badge is a white disk with a red lion passant in the centre of the disk. There is no official record of how the lion came to be included on the flag.{{cite web |url=http://www.dpac.tas.gov.au/divisions/executive/protocol_office/flags/tasmanian_flag |title=Tasmanian flag |accessdate=2008-09-17 |last=The Department of Premier and Cabinet |date=5 September 2008 |work= |publisher=tas.gov.au}} Where this design originated from is unknown, but it is assumed that the red lion is a link with England. This flag has remained almost unchanged since 1875, with only a slight change of the style of the lion when the flag was officially adopted by the government in 1975, although this was a mistake, as it had already been officially gazetted by the colonial government in 1876. ==History== Following the establishment of permanent British [[sovereignty|sovereign]] possession of the lands of Tasmania. Tasmania was granted [[responsible government|responsible self-government]] in 1856, but the colony did not receive its own flag until [[Queen Victoria]] had first proposed on 7 August 1869, that the colony of Tasmania (and the other Australian colonies) should adopt a [[Union flag]] defaced in the centre with the State Badge.{{cite web| url= http://members.iinet.net.au/~rwatson1/tasflag/ | title =Following The Tasmanian Flag. Its history and meaning| accessdate =2008-09-10| year= 2002| publisher =| language = }} Prior to the official adoption of a local flag, an unofficial merchant ensign was occasionally used. [[File:Van Diemen's Land Unofficial Merchant Ensign before 1875.svg|thumb|Unofficial merchant ensign used occasionally before the colony adopted an official flag]] [[File:1875 flag of Tasmania.svg|thumb|Flag of Tasmania, 9–23 November 1875]] The first local flag of Tasmania was adopted by proclamation of Tasmanian colonial [[Governor of Tasmania|Governor]] [[Frederick Aloysius Weld|Sir Frederick Weld]] on 9 November 1875. The flag had a white cross on a blue field, in the [[Flag terminology|canton]] was the [[Flag of the United Kingdom|Union Flag]], and in the fly was five five-pointed stars of the [[Crux|Southern Cross]]. The British [[Blue Ensign]] and [[Red Ensign]] (for use respectively by government vessels and by those privately owned) were to have a white cross added. At the fly end of each flag a Southern Cross was to be formed of white stars added above and below the horizontal arm of the cross. Two weeks later, on 23 November, those flags were officially abandoned because [[Henry Herbert, 4th Earl of Carnarvon]], the [[Secretary of State for the Colonies]] in London made it clear that only a single badge could be placed at the fly end of the ensign, as set out by rule of the [[Admiralty|British Admiralty]]. A year later the Tasmanian government decided, with the British Admiralty's approval, that the badge for the colony would be a red lion on a white disk. Originally the lion was to be gold in colour, above a golden torse, which the new flag omitted in favour of a more traditional red. A British Blue Ensign with the badge served Tasmanian government vessels, and privately owned vessels were to fly an un-defaced British Red Ensign. After Tasmania became a state on 1 January 1901, the Tasmanian Blue Ensign was rarely used, and was reserved for official purposes. Most vessels soon preferred to fly the [[Australian Red Ensign]]. On 3 December 1975, a government proclamation by [[Governor of Tasmania|Governor]] [[Stanley Burbury|Sir Stanley Burbury]], and endorsed by [[Premier of Tasmania|Premier]] [[Bill Neilson]] established it as the official Tasmanian flag, although it had technically already been 'officially' adopted when it was gazetted in 1876. Since that time it has been acceptable for private citizens to use the flag, although it is uncommon to see them doing so. ==Devices== The flag of Tasmania has two distinct symbols, the [[Union Flag]] (also known as the ''Union Jack''), and the [[List of Australian states and territories symbols|State Badge of Tasmania]]. As with the [[Flag of Australia]], the Union Flag is thought locally to symbolise Australia's history as six British colonies and the principles upon which the [[Australian Federation]] is based, Australian Flag SocietySource: Australian Flag Society although a more historic view sees its inclusion in the design as demonstrating loyalty to the [[British Empire]].Evans, I. 1918. ''The history of the Australian flag''. Evan Evans, Melbourne ==Construction== Unlike the national flag, the flag of Tasmania is not enshrined and protected by any acts of [[Parliament of Tasmania|state]] or [[Parliament of Australia|Commonwealth]] government. As a result, there are no official legal requirements for the construction of the flag of Tasmania. However tradition and decorum dictate that is should be: # the Union Jack occupying the upper quarter next the staff; # the fly is to be wholly blue, in line with the British Blue Ensign; # the State Badge is to be situated with its centre halfway between the edge of the canton and the end of the fly, and a third of the distance from the bottom of the flag; ==Colours== The colours of the flag, although not specified by the Flags Act, have been given the same [[Pantone]] specifications as the national flag. The Australian Government's ''Style Manual for Authors, Editors and Printers'' also gives [[CMYK color model|CMYK]] and [[RGB color model|RGB]] specifications for depicting the flag in print and on screen respectively.{{cite book |title= Style Manual for Authors, Editors and Printers|edition= 6th|year=2002 |publisher= John Wiley & Sons|location= Milton, Qld.|isbn=0-7016-3648-3}} {| class=wikitable width=60% style="text-align:center;" |- ! Scheme !style="background-color: #00008B; color: #FFFFFF"| Blue !style="background-color: #FF0000; color: #FFFFFF"| Red !style="background-color: #FFFFFF"| White |- | [[Pantone]] || 280 C || 185 C || Safe |- | [[RGB]]
([[Web colors#Hex triplet|Hex]])|| 0-0-139
(#00008B) || 255-0-0
(#FF0000) || 255-255-255
(#FFFFFF) |- | [[CMYK]] || 100%-80%-0%-0% || 0%-100%-100%-0% || 0%-0%-0%-0% |} ==Governor's flag== [[File:Flag of the Governor of Tasmania.svg|thumb|250px|right|Flag Ratio: 1:2]] [[Image:Flag of the Governor of Tasmania (1876–1977).svg|thumb|250px|Standard of the Governor, 1876-1977]] [[Image:Flag of the Governor of Tasmania (1875–1876).svg|thumb|250px|Standard of the Governor, 9–23 November 1875]] The [[Governor of Tasmania]], being the representative of the Tasmanian head of state, the [[Queen of Australia]], is officially granted a flag for use on all official occasions. It is identical in design and construction to the flag of Tasmania, except that it features a [[St. Edward's Crown]] above the badge to represent vice-regal power. When the Governor of Tasmania is resident at [[Government House, Hobart|Government House]] it is flown from the roof, and it is also used as a car flag. The Governor of Tasmania's flag was officially adopted in February 1977 by an act of the [[Parliament of Tasmania]]. ==See also== *[[List of Australian flags]] *[[Flags of the Governors of the Australian states]] ==Notes== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{FOTW|id=au-tas|title=Tasmania}} {{Portal bar|Heraldry|Tasmania}} {{Tasmania}} {{Australian Flags}} {{Union Flag}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Flag Of Tasmania}} [[Category:Tasmania]] [[Category:Flags of Australian states and territories|Tasmania]] [[Category:Blue Ensigns|Tasmania]] [[Category:Flags of the British Empire|Tasmania]] [[Category:Flags introduced in 1876]]

{{short description|Organisation in South East Asia for preservation of coral reefs by improving diver behavior }} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox organization | name = Green Fins | logo = [[File:Green Fins Hi-Res.jpg|160px|Green Fins logo]] | type = | founded_date = 2004 | tax_id = | registration_id = | founders = {{unbulleted list | [[United Nations Environment Programme]] | The Reef-World Foundation}} | location = {{Flag icon|UN}} [[UN Environment,]], | origins = | key_people = | area_served = {{unbulleted list | {{Flag icon|Dominican Republic}} [[Dominican Republic]] |{{Flag icon|Indonesia}} [[Indonesia]] | {{Flag icon|Malaysia}} [[Malaysia]] | {{Flag icon|Philippines}} [[Philippines]] | {{Flag icon|Thailand}} [[Thailand]] | {{Flag icon|Vietnam}} [[Vietnam]] | {{Flag icon|Maldives}} [[Maldives]] | {{Flag icon|Palau}} [[Palau]] }} | product = | mission = "To protect and conserve coral reefs by establishing and implementing environmentally friendly guidelines to promote a sustainable diving and snorkelling tourism industry." | focus = [[Environmentalism]] within the marine tourism sector | method = | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = c 500 | subsid = | owner = | Non-profit_slogan = Save Coral Reefs Today, Dive the Green Fins way. | former name = | homepage = http://www.greenfins.net/ | dissolved = | footnotes = }}
'''Green Fins''' is an approach to sustainable marine tourism activities operating in [[South East Asia]], [[Caribbean]] and the [[Indian Ocean]] that works with business operators, communities and governments. It helps to implement environmental standards for the diving and snorkelling industry through a code of conduct.<ref>[http://greenfins.net/content/uploads/COC%20-%20greenfins.net%20-%20English.pdf code of conduct] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130920073013/http://greenfins.net/content/uploads/COC%20-%20greenfins.net%20-%20English.pdf |date=20 September 2013 }}</ref> The overall aim of the initiative is to mitigate damaging impacts to the marine environment from the marine tourism sector and improve sustainability. The code of conduct is a set of 15 points designed to tackle the most common and detrimental effects of SCUBA diving and snorkelling activities on the habitat in which they operate.<ref name="code" />
==The Green Fins Approach== Dive centers and snorkel tour operators sign a membership form pledging to adhere to the Code of Conduct. Trained Green Fins assessors visit members annually to assess their compliance to the Code of Conduct and provide consultations for improvement, and environmental training to all staff at the member centre to support and build the capacity of those individuals to reduce their environmental impacts. Members often receive printed materials to support their efforts to reduce impacts to the marine environment including the Green Fins ICONS, which visually outline best practices for divers and snorkellers. These materials are available in many different languages. [[File:Divers coming into contact with coral.jpg|thumbnail|Divers coming into contact with coral]]
==History== Green Fins was established in 2004 as an initiative by the [[United Nations Environmental Programme]] (UNEP) and was first implemented by the Secretariat of the Coordinating Body on the Seas of East Asia (COBSEA).<ref name="icran" /> Green Fins was initiated and coordinated by COBSEA's secretariat as part of the effort to increase public awareness with an overall aim to better management practices that will contribute to the [[Marine conservation|conservation]] of [[coral reefs]] (and other associated marine [[ecosystems]] such as seagrass beds and mangroves) and reduce current unsustainable tourism practices.<ref name="cobsea" />
==Present== Currently there are eight active member countries of the Green Fins initiative with Singapore also supporting the initiative. [[Thailand]] and the [[Philippines]] started in 2004, [[Indonesia]] in 2007 and [[Malaysia]] in 2008, the [[Maldives]] and [[Vietnam]] starting in 2013 and the [[Dominican Republic]] in 2018. Each individual country is autonomous, running the approach to their governments own targets and objectives to fulfil the mission statement. This is done under the supervision of the Network Leader with the Network Leader Assistant as a supporting role. The position of the Network Leader is usually fulfilled by government staff who work under a relevant department overseeing the protection and control of either marine habitats or tourism.
The initiative is supported by the UK [[Charitable organization|charity]] The Reef-World Foundation. Their role as International Coordinators of the project is to assist countries with training and technical assistance under the direction of [[UNEP]] whilst helping to promote the countries various projects and successes on a global scale. In addition to this, Reef-World are also tasked with looking for additional funding to support the implementation and continued training of those that manage Green Fins in their respective countries. The Reef-World Foundation developed the Green Environmental Assessment Rating System (GEARS)<ref>http://www.reef-world.org/about_us.htm#GEARS</ref> to enable a results-based management approach through the Green Fins assessments that take place. The GEARS system allows a simple monitoring system that is able to measure the success of several objectives or milestones required to reach the overall goal enabling a results-based management approach . It does this with a green/yellow/red rating system, based on a weighted score for each objective, allowing for industry wide problems to be easily isolated and monitored.
In December 2012, The Reef-World Foundation in partnership with UNEP was successfully awarded a grant through the [[IUCN]] Mangroves for the Future Regional initiative. This saw the Green Fins network expand to [[Vietnam]] and the [[Maldives]] over a two-year project ending in November 2014.<ref>http://www.mangrovesforthefuture.org/grants/regional-initiatives/protecting-marine-ecosystems-in-mff-countries-using-the-green-fins-approach/</ref>
In April 2013 a research paper was accepted by the scientific journal Ocean and Coastal Management titled “The Green Fins approach for monitoring and promoting environmentally sustainable scuba diving operations in South East Asia” and was published in Volume 78, June 2013, pages 35–44.<ref>{{cite journal | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0964569113000719 | doi=10.1016/j.ocecoaman.2013.03.004 | volume=78 | title=The Green Fins approach for monitoring and promoting environmentally sustainable scuba diving operations in South East Asia | journal=Ocean | pages=35–44}}</ref> The authors of this paper are from The Reef-World Foundation with co-authors from Green Fins Thailand based at the Phuket Marine Biological Centre (PMBC), Phuket, Thailand.
January 2014 saw the launch of the Green Fins website,<ref>https://www.mangrovesforthefuture.org/news-and-media/news/asia-region/2014/mff-unep-regional-project-green-fins-goes-digital/</ref> which aims to provide a platform of information for Green Fins members, volunteers and coordinators of the initiate, government staff who help manage the project in their country and the general public who can download materials (posters, videos, leaflets, guidelines) to help provide educational information to divers, snorkellers and dive centre staff. The website also provides tourists the chance to search for Green Fins members and to view the environmental scores of diving areas as an average, helping them to decide which are the most environmentally friendly businesses and areas to dive or snorkel in.
The Green Fins initiative is free to join and all dive operators have the opportunity to be involved in the approach to help in battling to reduce their negative impacts.<ref name="reefworld" /> There are no costs involved in joining but members are expected to enter into the spirit that they can always improve their management policies in an effort to adhere to the Code of Conduct and protect the marine environment.
==Outreach and Environmental Activities== Green Fins encourages dive centres to engage staff, tourists, local businesses and communities in environmental activities such as beach and reef clean ups.<ref name="ziza" /> Reef monitoring is also promoted, Green Fins does not endorse a particular methodology leaving it to the choice of the dive centre depending on the resources available to them.
Several spin-off projects may be run alongside the annual assessments to further promote marine conservation, these have included 'Say No to Plastic' awareness campaigns, shark awareness with local communities and schools, and marine conservation education programs with local fishing communities. In 2012, Green Fins ran the first Green Fins Ambassador Program in Puerto Galera, Oriental Mindoro, Philippines. The program works with the most enthusiastic dive guides in the area, providing them with additional environmental training and encouraging these individuals to be environmental ambassadors within the diving, and surrounding communities. The pilot program was a huge success and has now been replicated in Moalboal and Malapascua, Cebu, Philippines, with plans to reach out to other diving locations. [[File:Green Fins flag.jpg|thumbnail|left|Green Fins flag]]
==References== <!--- See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Footnotes on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist|colwidth=40em |refs= <ref name="code">{{Cite web|url=http://www.greenfins.net/content/uploads/COC%20English_restricted.pdf |title=Green Fins Code of Conduct |publisher=Green Fins |year=2010 |accessdate=19 September 2010}}</ref> <ref name="icran">{{Cite web|url=http://www.icran.org/awareness-greenfins.html |title=Green Fins |publisher=International Coral Reef Action Network |year=2009 |accessdate=19 September 2010}}</ref> <ref name="cobsea">{{Cite web|url=http://www.cobsea.org/activities/activities_strategic_habitat.html |title=Coastal and marine habitat conservation |publisher=Coordinating Body on the Seas of East Asia |year=2008 |accessdate=19 September 2010}}</ref> <ref name="reefworld">{{Cite web|url=http://www.reef-world.org/greenfins.htm |title=Green Fins |year=2010 |publisher=The Reef-World Foundation |accessdate=19 September 2010}}</ref> <ref name="ziza">{{Cite web|url=http://ziz.asia/featured/how-green-are-your-fins/ |title=How Green are your Fins? |year=2010 |publisher=ZiZ Asia |accessdate=19 September 2010}}</ref> }}
==External links== * [http://www.greenfins.net/ Green Fins Official website ] * [http://www.greenfins.net/indonesia/ Green Fins Indonesia ] * [http://www.greenfins.net/vietnam/ Green Fins Vietnam ] * [http://www.greenfins.net/maldives/ Green Fins Maldives ] * [http://www.greenfins-malaysia.dmpm.nre.gov.my/ Green Fins Malaysia ] * [http://www.greenfins.net/philippines/ Green Fins Philippines ] * [http://www.greenfins-thailand.org/ Green Fins Thailand ] * [http://www.reef-world.org/ The Reef-World Foundation ]

page.title: In the Kingdom of the Goldhorn

revision.text:
{{italictitle}} [[File:Prizor iz filma v V kraljestvu Zlatoroga (2).jpg|thumbnail|Scene from the film]] '''''In the Kingdom of the Goldhorn''''' ({{lang-sl|V kraljestvu Zlatoroga}}) was the first [[List of Slovenian films|Slovene]] [[feature film]]. It was filmed in 1928 and 1929 and was directed, shot and edited by [[Janko Ravnik]]. It was a [[silent film]] shot in the [[black-and-white]] technique. The film was produced by the mountaineering club [[Skala (mountaineering club)|Skala]] and was 107 minutes long. Only about two thirds of the original {{convert|31|mm|adj=on}} film, i.e. the shortened 76-minute version, have been preserved until today.
The screenplay was written by [[Juš Kozak]]. The story tells about a trip by a student, a railway worker and a peasant to the [[Julian Alps]], the people they meet on their way, and their ascent to [[Mt. Triglav]]. The film features the mountaineers {{Interlanguage link multi|Joža Čop|sl}} (''Roban'') and {{Interlanguage link multi|Miha Potočnik|sl}} (''Klemen'').
''In the Kingdom of the Goldhorn'' was released on 29 August 1931 in [[Grand Hotel Union]] in Ljubljana. It was well received by the public, but criticised in reviews as amateurish. The last time the film was shown to the wider public was on its 80th anniversary in Grand Hotel Union in August 2011. A commemorative stamp with a motif from the film was published by the [[Post of Slovenia]] on this occasion.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.rtvslo.si/kultura/film/foto-80-let-prvega-slovenskega-igranega-celovecerca-v-kraljestvu-zlatoroga/265072 |title=Foto: 80 let prvega slovenskega igranega celovečerca V kraljestvu zlatoroga |language=Slovenian |trans-title=80 Years of the First Slovene Played Feature Film ''In the Kingdom of the Goldhorn'' |work==MMC RTV Slovenija |date=29 August 2011}}</ref>
==See also== *''[[The Slopes of Triglav]]'', the second Slovene feature film (1932) *''[[On Our Own Land]]'', the first Slovene sound feature film (1948)
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2015}} '''International Industrial Relations Institute''' was an international organisation that existed from 1925 to 1947.
The first proposal to establish an organisation for the "study and improvement of human conditions in industry" arose in the First International Conference on Industrial Welfare at the Chateau d' Argeronne, [[Forest of Argonne|Argonne]], [[France]] in 1922.<ref name=RO>{{cite journal|last1=Oldenziel|first1=Ruth|title=Gender and scientific management – Women and the history of the International Institute for Industrial Relations, 1922‐1946|journal=Journal of Management History|date=2000|volume=6|issue=7|pages=323-342}}</ref>
The institute was led by [[Mary van Kleeck]], an American social reformer, and [[Mary Fleddérus]], a Dutch activist,<ref name=RO/> and approached [[scientific management]] from a particular perspective: what they termed the [[human factor]]. From the outset it had close links with women's organisations such as the [[World YWCA|World Young Women's Christian Association]] and the [[Women's Trade Union League]].
It was founded by four distinct groups of activists:<ref name=RO/> # State employed women factory inspectors # World Young Women's Christian Association activists involved in industrial reform # women employed by industrial welfare units # enlightened industrialists employing large numbers of women
==Congresses== ===First Congress, Vlissingen 1925=== The first congress was held in [[Vlissingen]] in 1925.<ref name=RO/> This was entitled "The International Industrial Welfare (Personnel) Congress".<ref name="Carlson">{{cite journal|last1=Carlson|first1=Benny|title=The IRI and its Swedish Connection|journal=American Studies in Scandinavia|date=2007|volume=39|issue=1|pages=13-32}}</ref> The Institute was established and agreed to fold a congress every third year.<ref name="Carlson"/> [[Kerstin Hesselgren]] was elected President with three vice presidents: [[Cees van der Leeuw]], the dutch industrialist, Renee de Montmort from France, and Louise Odencrantz from the USA.
===Second Congress, Cambridge 1928=== The Second Congress was held in [[Girton College]] [[Cambridge]], 27 June - 2 July. The theme was the "Fundamental Relationships between all Sections of the Industrial Community."<ref name="Carlson"/> Kerstin Hesselgren resigned as President and Dorothy Cadbury as Treasurer. Cees van der Leeuw became the new president with Charles E. Jacob as treasurer.<ref name="Carlson"/>
===Third Congress, Amsterdam 1931=== The organisation sponsored [[Otto Neurath]]'s presentation "Das gegenwärtige Wachstum der Produktionskapazität der Welt" at the [[Amsterdam]] conference of 1931.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Neurath |first1=Otto |title=Empiricism and Sociology |date=1973 |publisher=Riedel |location=Dordrecht |isbn=978-90-277-0259-3}}</ref> Van Kleeck was the institute's associate director from 1928–1946.<ref name=SWHP>{{cite web|last1=McClurken|first1=Kara M.|title=van Kleeck, Mary|url=http://www.socialwelfarehistory.com/people/van-kleeck-mary/|website=Social Welfare History Project|publisher=The Social Welfare History Project|accessdate=13 June 2015}}</ref>
==Prominent members== * [[Adelaide Anderson]]<ref name=RO/> * [[Kerstin Hesselgren]]<ref name=RO/> * [[Lillian Moller Gilbreth]]<ref name=RO/>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:International economic organizations]]
